about:

comments.body: Ouch! We need this here too? If we need it, I guess this is ok. Would be nice to get away from this entirely as soon as we can.
We need it anywhere that python isn't actually a runtime requirement.
So, there are other cases I have encountered where it is not a runtime requirement, but I don't need this jinja version thing.
On Windows? And tests are run? Because the jpeg recipe here also had this issue independently. And it simply doesn't work for me without that.
Yes, I still had to require `python`, but no versioning stuff was necessary. Here is an [example](https://github.com/conda-forge/hdf5-feedstock/blob/master/recipe/meta.yaml#L40).
There is only one difference between the HDF5 recipe and this recipe. The HDF5 recipe actually has a run requirement (zlib). This smells more and more like a bug to me...

@msarahan did you see the conversation above - I feel that this behaviour (not properly binding Python version of no run requirements) is a bug. Do you agree? If so I can spend some time debugging it on conda build this weekend.

I'm not certain it's a bug, but it is certainly inconvenient.  We talked about this in today's call.  Your jinja is the best approach I've seen so far.  It makes logical sense to me to expect that the python version would be bound.  Can you think of any reason why one would want a different python than the one built with?  Maybe some build tool that runs only on py 27 (scons) but the output is py 3 OK?
But the bug IMHO is the fact that, if I add any runtime requirement _at all_,  as in nt python, then it suddenly resolved without the jinja. That seems weird to me.
Yes, that sounds like a bug to me.  Please file an issue first.  If you have time to work on it, I'd certainly appreciate it, but don't feel obligated.

As an example of this SCons point mentioned above, consider building MongoDB ( https://github.com/conda-forge/staged-recipes/pull/392 ). This builds with SCons, but will try to use Boost if available. If Boost is not available, it tries to build some subset of Boost. However, we have a dilemma. Do we spend time rebuilding something we have (Boost)? Or do we artificially restrict MongoDB to Python 2 in some way even though it does not depend on Python at all.

At least for my current problem, I'm seriously debating doing the same thing Homebrew did, which is to break Boost into a non-Python part and the Boost.Python part ( https://github.com/conda-forge/boost-feedstock/issues/1 ). That way if something needs Boost, but doesn't care about Python it doesn't suffer some weird restriction on where it can be installed.
For consistency, could you please add `number: 0` to the `build` section?

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +15,19 @@    - vs2010_openmp.patch  # [win and py34]

build:
  number: 0
  features:
